questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient comes to the OPD with complaints of a swelling on the eyelid. He gives history of a similar complaint multiple times in the past. The ophthalmologist diagnoses it as a case of recurrent chalazion and sends it for histopathological examination. What is the ophthalmologist excluding the probability of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma : This is a type of skin cancer that can occur on the eyelids , often resulting from prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light . While it can present as a lesion on the eyelid, its clinical appearance is usually different from that of a chalazion , typically showing more superficial, scaly, and ulcerative features .
  • • Option A.
  • • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • • type of skin cancer
  • • occur on the eyelids
  • • resulting from prolonged exposure to ultraviolet
  • • light
  • • lesion on the eyelid,
  • • clinical appearance is usually different from that of a chalazion
  • • superficial, scaly, and ulcerative features
  • • Option B . Basal Cell Carcinoma : The most common type of eyelid cancer , basal cell carcinoma often presents as a painless , slowly growing nodule on the eyelid with potential ulceration or a pearly appearance.
  • • Option B
  • • Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • • most common type of eyelid cancer
  • • basal cell carcinoma
  • • presents as a painless
  • • growing nodule on the eyelid
  • • potential ulceration
  • • Option C. Malignant Melanoma : This is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-containing cells known as melanocytes.
  • • Option C.
  • • Malignant Melanoma
  • • type of cancer that develops from the pigment-containing cells
  • • melanocytes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The histopathological examination of a recurrent chalazion is primarily conducted to exclude the possibility of sebaceous cell carcinoma .
  • ➤ histopathological examination of a recurrent chalazion
  • ➤ conducted to exclude the possibility
  • ➤ sebaceous cell carcinoma
  • ➤ Ref : pg 369 – eyelids- 6 th edition – comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 369 – eyelids- 6 th edition – comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought to the OPD with a history of drooping upper left eyelid since birth. What is the surgical procedure performed to correct ptosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Frontalis sling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Fasanella-Servat : This procedure is typically used for mild ptosis with good levator function . It involves resection of a small amount of the tarsal plate and Müller’s muscle but is not commonly used for congenital ptosis.
  • • Option B
  • • Fasanella-Servat
  • • used for mild ptosis with good levator function
  • • resection of a small amount of the tarsal plate and Müller’s muscle
  • • Option C . Levator Resection : Levator resection is preferred in cases of congenital ptosis with moderate levator function . The levator muscle is shortened, which helps to elevate the eyelid.
  • • Option C
  • • Levator Resection
  • • preferred in cases of congenital ptosis with moderate levator function
  • • Option D. Levator Advancement : Levator advancement is similar to levator resection and may be used for ptosis with good levator function . This procedure involves advancing the levator aponeurosis to effectively shorten and strengthen the muscle, helping to lift the eyelid.
  • • Option D.
  • • Levator Advancement
  • • levator resection and may be used for ptosis with good levator function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For congenital ptosis , especially with poor levator function , the Frontalis Sling operation is often the surgery of choice.
  • ➤ congenital ptosis
  • ➤ poor levator function
  • ➤ Frontalis Sling
  • ➤ Ref : pg 380/ eye lids/ 6 th edition comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 380/ eye lids/ 6 th edition comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: The tears secreted by the lacrimal glands are drained via the lacrimal drainage apparatus into which part of the nose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inferior meatus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Middle meatus:
  • • Option B. Middle meatus:
  • • It is site of opening of the nasolacrimal duct after Dacryocystorhinostomy. (DCR)
  • • site of opening of the nasolacrimal duct
  • • Dacryocystorhinostomy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The opening of the nasolacrimal duct is located in the inferior meatus .
  • ➤ opening of the nasolacrimal duct
  • ➤ inferior meatus
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of a painless, localized swelling on their eyelid that has been present for several weeks. The patient reports that the swelling has gradually increased in size and is not associated with any discomfort or redness. On examination, a firm, non-tender nodule is palpated on the upper eyelid. The patient is diagnosed with a chalazion, a chronic inflammatory granuloma of Meibomian gland. Where are the involved glands located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tarsal plate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Eye lash : The glands associated with the eyelashes are the glands of Zeis and Moll .
  • • Option B. Eye lash : The glands associated with the eyelashes are the glands of Zeis and Moll .
  • • Option B.
  • • Eye lash
  • • glands associated with the eyelashes
  • • glands of Zeis and Moll
  • • Option C. Conjunctiva : While the Meibomian glands open at the lid margin near the conjunctiva , they are not located in the conjunctiva itself.
  • • Option C. Conjunctiva : While the Meibomian glands open at the lid margin near the conjunctiva , they are not located in the conjunctiva itself.
  • • Option C.
  • • Conjunctiva
  • • Meibomian glands open at the lid margin
  • • conjunctiva
  • • Option D. Iris : There are no glands in the iris .
  • • Option D. Iris : There are no glands in the iris .
  • • Option D.
  • • Iris
  • • no glands in the iris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Meibomian glands are located in the tarsal plates of the eyelids .
  • ➤ The Meibomian glands are located in the tarsal plates of the eyelids .
  • ➤ Meibomian glands
  • ➤ tarsal plates of the eyelids
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Anita, a 32-year-old female patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of persistent tearing since several months and occasional eye discharge in her left eye. She notices that her left eye frequently waters, especially when she is outdoors or exposed to windy conditions. She has no history of eye trauma or previous eye surgeries. The ophthalmologist suspects a nasolacrimal duct obstruction in the left eye. What is the normal length of the duct involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 12 to 18 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 5 to 10 mm : This length is of the body of the lacrimal sac .
  • • Option A.
  • • 5 to 10 mm
  • • length is of the body
  • • lacrimal sac
  • • Option B. 20 to 25 mm : This is the length of the inferior meatus .
  • • Option B.
  • • 20 to 25 mm
  • • length of the inferior meatus
  • • Option D. 1 to 2 mm: This is the length of the vertical part of the canaliculus .
  • • Option D.
  • • 1 to 2 mm:
  • • length of the vertical part of the canaliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal length of the nasolacrimal duct , which drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity , is approximately 12 to 18 mm
  • ➤ normal length
  • ➤ nasolacrimal duct
  • ➤ drains tears from the lacrimal sac
  • ➤ nasal cavity
  • ➤ 12 to 18 mm
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with persistent tearing, recurrent eye infections, and crusting around the left eye since birth. The pediatrician suspects nasolacrimal duct obstruction and suggests Crigler’s massage and prescribes antibiotics. In which direction is the involved duct directed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Downwards, backwards and laterally

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The NLD runs in a bony canal formed by maxilla and inferior turbinate directed downwards, backwards and laterally .
  • • NLD runs in a bony canal
  • • maxilla and inferior turbinate
  • • downwards, backwards and laterally
  • • Students should read the question carefully. The direction of the NLD is not to be confused with the direction of the canaliculus which is directed medially.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nasolacrimal duct is directed downwards, backwards and laterally .
  • ➤ nasolacrimal duct is directed downwards, backwards and laterally
  • ➤ Ref : pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The most common cause of congenital lacrimal sac obstruction is due to imperforate Valve of Hasner. Where is this valve located?

options.label: A
options.text: At the junction of lacrimal sac and NLD

options.label: B
options.text: In the middle part of NLD

options.label: C
options.text: At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus

options.label: D
options.text: Between the common canaliculus and lacrimal sac

questions.correct_answer: C. At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option D - Between Common Canaliculus and Lacrimal Sac : This is the location of the Valve of Rosenmuller.
  • • Option D
  • • Between Common Canaliculus and Lacrimal Sac
  • • location of the Valve of Rosenmuller.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The valve of Hasner is located at the opening of NLD in inferior meatus.
  • ➤ valve of Hasner
  • ➤ located
  • ➤ opening of NLD in inferior meatus.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 460 / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ pg 460 / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Lacrimal glands are derived from which embryonic layer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Surface ectoderm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Mesoderm : The mesoderm forms structures such as muscles, bones, connective tissues, and parts of the cardiovascular and lymphatic systems . It is not involved in the development of the lacrimal glands.
  • • Option B. Mesoderm
  • • forms structures such as muscles, bones, connective tissues,
  • • cardiovascular and lymphatic systems
  • • Option C. Neuroectoderm: The neuroectoderm primarily gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems, including the brain and spinal cord. It is not responsible for the development of the lacrimal glands.
  • • Option C. Neuroectoderm:
  • • gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems,
  • • brain and spinal cord.
  • • Option D. Neuroectoderm & mesoderm: This combination is incorrect for the development of the lacrimal glands . While both neuroectoderm and mesoderm are crucial for various aspects of embryonic development, they do not contribute to the formation of the lacrimal glands.
  • • Option D. Neuroectoderm & mesoderm:
  • • combination is incorrect
  • • development of the lacrimal glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lacrimal glands are derived from the surface ectoderm
  • ➤ lacrimal glands
  • ➤ derived from the surface ectoderm
  • ➤ Ref : pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6 th edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6 th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Identify the gland marked with a red arrow:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meibomian gland

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Gland of Moll: These are apocrine sweat glands found in the eyelids . They are different from the tarsal (Meibomian) glands and are associated with the hair follicles of the eyelashes .
  • • Option B
  • • Gland of Moll:
  • • apocrine sweat glands found in the eyelids
  • • associated with the hair follicles of the eyelashes
  • • Option C. Gland of Zeis : These are small sebaceous glands associated with the eyelashes and are not the same as the tarsal glands . They secrete a substance that lubricates the eyelashes.
  • • Option C.
  • • Gland of Zeis
  • • small sebaceous glands
  • • eyelashes and are not the same as the tarsal glands
  • • Option D. Gland of Krausse: These are minor glands in the eyelid.
  • • Option D.
  • • Gland of Krausse:
  • • minor glands in the eyelid.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tarsal glands are the same as the Meibomian glands , which are sebaceous glands within the eyelids contributing to the tear film.
  • ➤ tarsal glands
  • ➤ same as the Meibomian glands
  • ➤ sebaceous glands within the eyelids
  • ➤ tear film.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The glands of Zeis open into?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lash follicle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Conjunctiva : The glands of Zeis do not open into the conjunctiva. The conjunctiva is a mucous membrane.
  • • Option A. Conjunctiva : The glands of Zeis do not open into the conjunctiva. The conjunctiva is a mucous membrane.
  • • Option A.
  • • Conjunctiva
  • • glands of Zeis
  • • not open into the conjunctiva.
  • • Option B. Lacrimal sac : The lacrimal sac is part of the tear drainage system and is not connected to the glands of Zeis . It collects tears from the eyes and drains them into the nasolacrimal duct.
  • • Option B. Lacrimal sac : The lacrimal sac is part of the tear drainage system and is not connected to the glands of Zeis . It collects tears from the eyes and drains them into the nasolacrimal duct.
  • • Option B.
  • • Lacrimal sac
  • • lacrimal sac is part of the tear drainage system
  • • not connected to the glands of Zeis
  • • Option D . Lid margin: Meibomian glands open at the lid margin.
  • • Option D . Lid margin: Meibomian glands open at the lid margin.
  • • Option D
  • • Lid margin:
  • • Meibomian glands
  • • lid margin.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glands of Zeis open into the eyelash follicles (Option C). They are sebaceous glands that secrete an oily substance to lubricate the eyelashes.
  • ➤ The glands of Zeis open into the eyelash follicles (Option C). They are sebaceous glands that secrete an oily substance to lubricate the eyelashes.
  • ➤ glands of Zeis open into the eyelash follicles
  • ➤ sebaceous glands that secrete an oily substance

  • ➤ Ref : pg 499/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 499/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The lacrimal gland is present in which quadrant of the orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superolateral

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Inferolateral: The inferolateral quadrant contains other structures like the orbital floor and muscles.
  • • Option B
  • • Inferolateral:
  • • inferolateral quadrant
  • • structures like the orbital floor and muscles.
  • • Option C. Superonasal : This area includes structures such as the trochlea of the superior oblique muscle .
  • • Option C.

  • • Option D. Inferonasal : It includes other anatomical structures like the nasolacrimal duct .
  • • Option D.

questions.text: The order of different layers in the tear film from anterior to posterior are: L-lipid, M-mucous, A- aqueous
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L-A-M

questions.text: Identify the test:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Jones test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Schirmer test : Measures total tear secretion . A value <10mm is suggestive of dry eye .
  • • Option A. Schirmer test
  • • Measures total tear secretion
  • • <10mm is suggestive of dry eye
  • • Option B. Tear film break up time: Indicator of adequacy of mucin component of tear film . Less than 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film . The image below shows multiple dry spots in a fluorescein-stained tear film.
  • • Option B. Tear film break up time:
  • • Indicator
  • • adequacy of mucin component of tear film
  • • Less
  • • 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jones test is the test to assess the patency of the lacrimal pathway using fluorescein dye.
  • ➤ Ref : Patel J, Levin A, Patel BC. Epiphora Clinical Testing. [Updated 2023 Jul 25]. In: Stat Pearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): Stat Pearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557424/
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, presented to the OPD with grade 3 ectropion more pronounced on the lateral half of the left lower lid. Identify the surgical procedure of choice:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Modified Kuhnt Szymanowski

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Lateral Tarsal Stripping : This procedure is used to correct lower eyelid laxity and malposition . It involves the surgical tightening of the lateral lower eyelid by excising a strip of the lateral tarsal conjunctiva and lower eyelid retractors . It helps to reposition and stabilize the lower eyelid, often used in cases of entropion or ectropion.
  • • Option B
  • • Lateral Tarsal Stripping
  • • procedure is used to correct lower eyelid laxity and malposition
  • • surgical tightening
  • • lateral lower eyelid by excising a strip of the lateral tarsal conjunctiva
  • • lower eyelid retractors
  • • Option C. Wies Procedure : The Wies procedure is a surgical technique used to correct minor-to-moderate entropion , particularly when it involves the lower eyelid . It involves a horizontal tightening of the eyelid margin without shortening the horizontal length of the eyelid . A small section of the outer eyelid is removed, and then the eyelid is sutured to tighten and reposition it, which helps in turning the eyelid margin outward, correcting the entropion.
  • • Option C.
  • • Wies Procedure
  • • Wies procedure is a surgical technique used to correct minor-to-moderate entropion
  • • involves the lower eyelid
  • • horizontal tightening
  • • eyelid margin
  • • without shortening the horizontal length of the eyelid
  • • Option D. Z-Plasty : Z-plasty is a surgical technique used to revise scars , but it's also employed in eyelid surgeries for conditions like ectropion . It involves creating two triangular flaps of equal dimension that are transposed to reorient and lengthen the scar or contracted tissue . In eyelid surgery, this technique can be used to redistribute tissue, correct cicatricial ectropion, or address eyelid deformities that result from scarring.
  • • Option D.
  • • Z-Plasty
  • • is a surgical technique used to revise scars
  • • employed in eyelid surgeries
  • • ectropion
  • • creating two triangular flaps of equal dimension
  • • transposed to reorient and lengthen the scar or contracted tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with Grade 3 Ectropion with lateral lid laxity, Kuhnt-Szymanowski procedure is the treatment of choice.
  • ➤ patients with Grade 3 Ectropion
  • ➤ lateral lid laxity, Kuhnt-Szymanowski procedure is the treatment of choice.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 376/ eye lids/6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 376/ eye lids/6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: What surgical procedure involves the plication of lower lid retractors to correct entropion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Jones procedure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Weis Procedure : The Weiss procedure , is designed to correct entropion , specifically of the lower eyelid . It involves a horizontal tightening of the eyelid margin , usually without shortening the horizontal length of the eyelid . A small section of the outer eyelid is removed and then sutured to reposition and tighten the eyelid, thereby correcting the inward turning of the eyelid.
  • • Option A.
  • • Weis Procedure
  • • Weiss procedure
  • • correct entropion
  • • lower eyelid
  • • horizontal tightening of the eyelid margin
  • • without shortening the horizontal length of the eyelid
  • • Option C. Quickert’s Procedure : Quickert’s procedure is a surgical technique specifically designed to correct involutional entropion .
  • • Option C.
  • • Quickert’s Procedure
  • • surgical technique
  • • correct involutional entropion
  • • Quickert sutures tighten lower lid retractors . Accordingly, the safety, simplicity, quickness, and overall patient satisfaction have been cited as reasons to consider the Quickert procedure for patients in whom these features would be valuable, or patients with higher operative risk
  • • Quickert sutures tighten lower lid retractors
  • • safety, simplicity, quickness,
  • • overall patient satisfaction have been cited
  • • Option D. Modified Wheeler Operation : The Modified Wheeler Operation is another surgical technique for correcting lower eyelid entropion . It involves resecting a part of the tarsal plate along with the adjacent conjunctiva and then suturing the edges . This technique is often used when there's a need to shorten the horizontal length of the eyelid due to laxity.
  • • Option D.
  • • Modified Wheeler Operation
  • • is another surgical technique for correcting lower eyelid entropion
  • • involves resecting a part of the tarsal plate
  • • adjacent conjunctiva
  • • suturing the edges

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jones procedure is plication of lower lid retractors to correct entropion .
  • ➤ Jones procedure
  • ➤ plication of lower lid retractors to correct entropion
  • ➤ Ref : 373/eye lids/6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : 373/eye lids/6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient came with complaints of a painful swelling in the region of left lacrimal sac associated with epiphora. He also gives history of fever and malaise. On examination, it is noted that the swelling is red, hot, firm and tender. The eyelids and cheek are also red and oedematous. On asking, he gives a history of having a dental abscess few days back. The ophthalmologist makes a diagnosis of Acute dacryocystitis in the stage of cellulitis. What treatment should be provided to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antibiotics

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dacryocystorhinostomy: Dacryocystorhinostomy is a surgical procedure used to create a new tear drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity . This is typically indicated in chronic dacryocystitis or after the acute infection has been resolved. It is not the first-line treatment for acute dacryocystitis in the cellulitis stage.
  • • Option A. Dacryocystorhinostomy:
  • • surgical procedure used to create a new tear drainage pathway
  • • lacrimal sac
  • • nasal cavity
  • • indicated in chronic dacryocystitis
  • • not the first-line treatment
  • • Option B. Abscess Drainage: Abscess drainage is performed if there is a formation of an abscess , which is a collection of pus . In acute dacryocystitis, abscess formation can occur, but drainage is indicated only if an abscess has actually formed.
  • • Option B. Abscess Drainage:
  • • formation of an abscess
  • • collection of pus
  • • Option D. Dacryocystectomy: Dacryocystectomy, the removal of the lacrimal sac , is rarely performed and typically reserved for cases where other treatments have failed or are not appropriate. It is not a standard treatment for acute dacryocystitis.
  • • Option D. Dacryocystectomy:
  • • removal of the lacrimal sac
  • • performed
  • • typically reserved for cases
  • • treatments have failed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the stage of cellulitis in acute dacryocystitis , the most appropriate treatment is the administration of systemic Antibiotics . This approach is aimed at controlling the infection and preventing further complications . Once the acute infection is resolved, further evaluation and possibly surgical intervention (like dacryocystorhinostomy) might be considered, especially if there are underlying issues like nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • ➤ stage of cellulitis in acute dacryocystitis
  • ➤ appropriate treatment is the administration of systemic Antibiotics
  • ➤ controlling the infection and preventing further complications
  • ➤ Ref : pg 395/lacrimal apparatus/6 th edition comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 395/lacrimal apparatus/6 th edition comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 62/eyelids/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition

questions.text: A patient complains of a painful, swollen bump on the eyelid. Upon examination, a tender, red lump is observed on the eyelid. The patient is diagnosed with hordeolum internum. Which gland is involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meibomian gland

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Zeis Gland : The Zeis glands are sebaceous glands associated with the eyelashes . Infection of a Zeis gland leads to an external hordeolum, commonly known as a stye.
  • • Option B
  • • Zeis Gland
  • • Zeis glands are sebaceous glands
  • • eyelashes
  • • Option C. Moll Glands : Moll glands are sweat glands located near the eyelashes .
  • • Option C.
  • • Moll Glands
  • • sweat glands located near the eyelashes
  • • Option D. Conjunctiva : Infection of conjunctiva causes conjunctivitis .
  • • Option D. Conjunctiva
  • • conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hardeolum internum is infection of Meibomian Glands .
  • ➤ Hardeolum internum
  • ➤ Meibomian Glands
  • ➤ Ref : Pg 369/ eyelids/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Pg 369/ eyelids/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: Identify the strip used in the following test:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5*35 mm whatman 41 filter paper

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Schirmer’s test
  • • Schirmer’s test
  • • Schirmer's test is used to determine whether the eye produces enough tears to keep it moist . The test is performed by placing filter paper inside the lower lid of the eye . After 5 minutes , the paper is removed and tested for its moisture content .
  • • determine whether the eye produces enough tears
  • • keep it moist
  • • performed by placing filter paper inside the lower lid of the eye
  • • 5 minutes
  • • paper is removed and tested for its moisture content
  • • A Schirmer test score >10 mm in 5 minutes is widely accepted as the normal value, whereas a score <5 mm is indicative of tear deficiency.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ B. 5*35 mm whatman 41 filter paper is used for preparing Schirmer strips.
  • ➤ B. 5*35 mm whatman 41 filter paper
  • ➤ Ref : Pg 389/ lacrimal apparatus/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Pg 389/ lacrimal apparatus/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the given clinical syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Exotropia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid , is a key component of blepharophimosis syndrome . It's often present from birth and can be significant, sometimes impairing vision.
  • • Option A. Ptosis:
  • • drooping of the upper eyelid
  • • blepharophimosis syndrome
  • • Option C. Epicanthus Inversus: Epicanthus inversus is a characteristic feature of blepharophimosis syndrome . It involves a fold of skin that arises from the lower eyelid and covers the inner corner (canthus) of the eye.
  • • Option C. Epicanthus Inversus:
  • • feature of blepharophimosis syndrome
  • • Option D. Blepharophimosis: Blepharophimosis, the reduction in the horizontal width of the eyelids , is a defining feature of this syndrome. It results in a narrow palpebral fissure (eyelid opening).
  • • Option D. Blepharophimosis:
  • • reduction in the horizontal width of the eyelids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given clinical picture shows blepharophimosis, epicanthus inversus and ptosis, indicating a diagnosis of Blepharophimosis syndrome . Exotropia is not a part of this syndrome.
  • ➤ clinical picture shows blepharophimosis,
  • ➤ epicanthus inversus and ptosis, indicating a diagnosis of Blepharophimosis syndrome
  • ➤ Ref : pg 59/ eyelids/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 59/ eyelids/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: Identify the following lid tumour:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Malignant Melanoma : Appears as a rapidly growing pigmented lesion that can have variable colors , with an irregular border and may arise de novo or from a pre-existing mole.
  • • Option B.
  • • Malignant Melanoma
  • • rapidly growing pigmented lesion
  • • variable colors
  • • irregular border
  • • Option C . Squamous Cell Carcinoma : Typically manifests as a scaly, erythematous, and sometimes ulcerated lesion that can be mistaken for a benign lesion but has potential for local invasion and metastasis.
  • • Option C
  • • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • • manifests as a scaly, erythematous, and sometimes ulcerated lesion
  • • Option D. Keratoacanthoma : Usually emerges as a dome-shaped, flesh-colored nodule with a central keratin-filled crater and may spontaneously regress over time.
  • • Option D.
  • • Keratoacanthoma
  • • dome-shaped, flesh-colored nodule
  • • central keratin-filled crater

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given clinical image shows a pearly nodule with telangiectatic vessels , on the lower eyelid suggestive of Basal Cell Carcinoma.
  • ➤ clinical image shows a pearly nodule with telangiectatic vessels
  • ➤ lower eyelid
  • ➤ Basal Cell Carcinoma.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 23/eyelids/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref : pg 23/eyelids/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition

questions.text: What is the immediate treatment at this stage of dacryocystitis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antibiotics & drainage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given clinical picture is suggestive of acute dacryocystitis with cellulitis and abscess formation . Thus, patient needs to be treated with systemic antibiotics and drainage of abscess.
  • ➤ suggestive of acute dacryocystitis with cellulitis and abscess formation

questions.text: Which organism causes Blepharitis acarica?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Demodex folliculorum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Staphylococcus epidermidis : Staphylococcus epidermidis is a part of the normal skin flora and is also found in the mucous membranes . It can be a cause of blepharitis , typically contributing to bacterial blepharitis , but is not the organism associated with Blepharitis acarica.
  • • Option A:
  • • Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • • part of the normal skin flora
  • • found in the mucous membranes
  • • cause of blepharitis
  • • bacterial blepharitis
  • • Option B: Ascaris : Ascaris refers to a genus of parasitic roundworms . Ascaris lumbricoides is the species responsible for ascariasis in humans , affecting the intestines . It is not involved in eye infections or conditions like blepharitis.
  • • Option B:
  • • Ascaris
  • • genus of parasitic roundworms
  • • Ascaris lumbricoides
  • • species responsible for ascariasis in humans
  • • intestines
  • • Option D: Propionibacterium : Propionibacterium, known as Cutibacterium, includes species such as Propionibacterium acnes , which is part of the normal skin flora and has been implicated in acne development. While it can be associated with eyelid margin inflammation, it is not the causative agent of Blepharitis acarica.
  • • Option D:
  • • Propionibacterium
  • • Cutibacterium,
  • • species such as Propionibacterium acnes
  • • normal skin flora
  • • implicated in acne development.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Demodex folliculorum is the organism that causes Blepharitis acarica , a condition characterized by infestation of the eyelash follicles leading to blepharitis.
  • ➤ Demodex folliculorum
  • ➤ organism that causes Blepharitis acarica
  • ➤ infestation of the eyelash follicles leading to blepharitis.
  • ➤ Ref : Singh A, Acharya M, Mathur U. Commentary: Demodex - Microscopic residents of the ocular biome. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2021 Sep;69(9):2394-2395. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_1137_21. PMID: 34427229; PMCID: PMC8544099.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Singh A, Acharya M, Mathur U. Commentary: Demodex - Microscopic residents of the ocular biome. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2021 Sep;69(9):2394-2395. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_1137_21. PMID: 34427229; PMCID: PMC8544099.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came with the complaints of sandy or gritty sensation and itching in the eyes with worsening of symptoms in the evening. After examining and carrying out tests on the patient, a diagnosis of dry eye disease is made. For management, the graded approach of dry disease is planned. According to level 2 of this approach, all of the following are included, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Permanent punctal occlusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Secretagogues : Secretagogues are medications that stimulate the production of tears . These are often considered at higher levels of dry eye treatment when conservative measures are insufficient.
  • • Option A
  • • Secretagogues
  • • medications that stimulate the production of tears
  • • higher levels of dry eye treatment
  • • Option B . Moisture Chamber Spectacles : Moisture chamber spectacles help to maintain humidity and reduce tear evaporation , and they are often recommended in Level 2 management for providing symptomatic relief in moderate dry eye.
  • • Option B
  • • Moisture Chamber Spectacles
  • • help to maintain humidity and reduce tear evaporation
  • • Option D. Nonpreserved Tear Substitutes : Nonpreserved tear substitutes are often recommended as a first-line treatment in the initial levels of DEWS guidelines due to their lower potential for causing irritation, especially in patients who require frequent instillation of artificial tears.
  • • Option D.
  • • Nonpreserved Tear Substitutes
  • • often recommended as a first-line treatment in the initial levels of DEWS guidelines
  • • lower potential

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Permanent Punctal Occlusion is included in Level 3 of DEWS II Guidelines.
  • ➤ Permanent Punctal Occlusion
  • ➤ Level 3 of DEWS II Guidelines.
  • ➤ Ref : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 162
  • ➤ Ref : KANSKI 9 TH EDITION PAGE 162

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is recently approved for treatment of dry eye disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lifitegrast

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Natalizumab : Natalizumab is a monoclonal anti-integrin antibody used to treat Crohn's disease or multiple sclerosis.
  • • Option A
  • • Natalizumab
  • • monoclonal anti-integrin antibody used to treat Crohn's disease
  • • Option C. Abciximab : Abciximab is a monoclonal anti-glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antibody used to prevent thrombosis during percutaneous coronary intervention.
  • • Option C.
  • • Abciximab
  • • monoclonal anti-glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antibody
  • • prevent thrombosis
  • • Option D. Cilengitide : an RGD pentapeptide ανβ3 and ανβ5 integrin inhibitor in development for glioblastoma and other malignancies.
  • • Option D.
  • • Cilengitide
  • • RGD pentapeptide ανβ3 and ανβ5 integrin inhibitor in development for glioblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lifitegrast is used for the treatment of dry eye .
  • ➤ Lifitegrast is used for the treatment of dry eye
  • ➤ Ref : AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 415
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 415
